description: Recommended for science majors and engineering students. Classical laws of motion; interactions between particles; conservation laws and symmetry principles; particle and rigid body motion; gravitation, harmonic motion.
name: PRINCIPLES I

values.comments:
PHYS 150 topics include classical laws of motion, interactions between particles,
conservation laws and symmetry principles, particle and rigid body motion, gravitation,
and harmonic motion.
Several students found that they had already covered the course’s material in their
high school physics class; others felt that the course was very challenging and that it was
easy to fall behind. Many students were surprised at the lack of calculus used,
considering this class is an engineering-level physics course.
Students described Professor Hollebeek as “enthusiastic” and “genuinely
accessible.” However, some wrote that lectures could get “boring,” and that they weren’t
always reflective of homework and exam problems.
Students recommended this class for science majors and engineering students.

The course covers classical laws of motion, interactions between particles,
conservation laws, and symmetry principles. It also touches upon particle and rigid body
motion, gravitation, and harmonic motion. Co-requisites for this course are Math 104
and Physics 150 lab.
Students overall felt that this was a good introduction to physics course. They
found it to be similar to their high school physics courses. One student also said that he
found the in-class demonstrations to be fun.
Students gave raving reviews about Professor Lipeles’ teaching style. They
commented that he was “always clear” and “always helpful.” However, one student
thought that Professor Lipeles was unable to communicate the information clearly and
without a background of physics in high school, it was hard to keep up. They also said
that he had “great energy in class” and was “easy to approach.”
Students found that this course was “interesting overall.” It was pretty easy,
especially if the students took physics in high school. This class is recommended for
science majors and engineering students. This class fulfills the physical world sector.
